did.unittitle: Library Company of Philadelphia Quarter of a Millennium gift collection

bioghist.p: The Library Company of Philadelphia is an independent research library concentrating on American society and culture from the 17th through 19th centuries. It was founded in 1731 by Benjamin Franklin as a subscription library supported by its shareholders, as it is to this day. Free and open to the public, the Library Company houses an extensive non-circulating collection of rare books, manuscripts, broadsides, ephemera, and works of art.

scopecontent.p: This is a collection of 33 commemorative volumes sent to the Library Company of Philadelphia in honor of its 250th anniversary. Most volumes are facsimile editions of significant texts, and were sent to the Library Company from various European national and university libraries. The collection also includes copies of talks given at the Quarter of a Millennium celebration, an attendee information packet, two commemorative medals, and a small number of letters of congratulation.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.
